() , ? asked the Minister of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development:
(i) the total number of gem-mining permits issued from 2020 to 2024, in relation to each year;
(ii) the number of gem mines located in the Badulla District for which licences were issued during that period, in relation to each Divisional Secretary's Division, separately;
(iii) out of those gem mines, the number of those which have been backfilled in accord-ance with proper standards after ending the operations; and
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Chathuranga Abeysinghe - Deputy Minister of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development) , .
INDUSTRIAL PARK IN GOLUWAMULLA, ELPITIYA: DETAILS
asked the Minister of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development:
(i) whether an industrial park has been estab-lished in Grama Niladhari Division No. 29- Goluwamulla within the Elpitiya Divisional Secretary's Division;
(ii) if so, the total extent of land of the industrial park concerned in acres;
(iii) the extent of land which has already been developed by now in acres, out of the aforementioned extent of land;
(iv) the name of the organization that has carried out the development activities in it; and
(v) the industries that have already been estab-lished in the industrial park concerned and the industries to be established in future, separately;
( ) (The Hon. Chathuranga Abeysinghe) , . visit . project , - , allocate , .
INDUSTRIAL PARKS IN SRI LANKA: CURRENT STATUS
() , ? asked the Minister of Industry and Entrepreneurship Development:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) the number of industries currently operating in the industrial parks in Sri Lanka, their production and the business type they be-long to, separately; (ii) the number of industries that have been operated in the industrial parks, but have been closed down now; (iii) whether industrial parks are currently oper-ating at their maximum capacity; (iv) whether there is space in the said industrial parks for starting new industries; and (v) whether a census has been conducted re-garding the number of small and medium-scale industries operating in Sri Lanka?

(b) Will he also inform this House - (i) whether it has been planned to start new industrial parks; (ii) if so, the plans that have been made for that; and (iii) the expected way of raising capital for the above purpose?
) ( - ) (The Hon. Darmapriya Wijesinghe on behalf of the Hon. Ruwan Wijeweera) - (1):

(a) Will he inform this House the - (i) total number of wild elephants living in Sri Lanka; (ii) number of wild elephants and wild tuskers that were killed due to the human-elephant conflict in each of the years from 2020 to 2024, separately; (iii) key factors that have contributed to the hu-man-elephant conflict; and (iv) measures that have been taken to control the human-elephant conflict?

: OPENING CEREMONY OF SHOPS AT BASTION MAWATHA:

() , ? asked the Minister of Urban Development, Construc-tion and Housing:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether an advance payment of Rs. 17,639,938.86 had been made to TRIAD Company, out of the total expenditure of Rs. 19,301,403.61 for the media coverage of the opening ceremony of 42 shops at Bastion Mawatha, Pettah; (ii) whether the procurement process had been followed in that regard; (iii) the person who has the authority to approve the aforesaid advance payment; (iv) the purpose of spending such a large amount of money for the media coverage, as aforementioned; (v) the reason for not providing the aforesaid media coverage through a government me-dia institution, if any media coverage was provided for the aforesaid ceremony?

Especially about Adani's wind power project and his pulling out from that, the Government is saying all sorts of things. It is Adani who pulled out from that because Adani did not want to do business here. The rate they offered, US Dollars 0.08 cents, was agreed to by the Ceylon Electricity Board. And, Adani did not have the same facilities that were given to the other proposed 50 megawatt wind power project in Mannar. With regard to the Adani project, the Environmental Impact Assessment had already been done; the Bird Migration Report had

already been done. Adani had to do all that. Also, Adani had to build a jetty in Mannar to bring the wind turbines. Later, the jetty was supposed to be used for fishermen. Then, the rate Adani agreed on was something that the CEB proposed; it was not Adani who imposed that. If we take the transparency of it, whether a tender procedure was followed or not, it is a US Dollars 1 billion investment. So, if you wanted to, you could have renegotiated it. The reason why people went to court against the project earlier was because they had environmental issues. That, we also had. Some people in Mannar had issues with regard to certain locations where the turbines were going to be fixed. We conveyed that to the relevant authorities and they were happy to look into it. But, now, Adani has pulled out. Adani was going to add 488 megawatts to the Grid. It was 488 megawatts! Earlier, I mentioned the number of units a litre of oil could produce; it is 4 litres per unit. So, whatever progres-sive steps that the previous Government had taken to achieve the target of a 70 per cent renewable energy input into the Grid by 2030, this Government has now destroyed. The Government has no plan. Therefore, our energy sector is again under threat.

, This audit que-ry is issued in addition to the audit query No. ENR/A/CPC/1/21/AQ/05 dated 05th July, 2022 issued by me regarding the same subject. However, your comments to that query has not yet been received title . 1 :

The accumulated overpayment of dealer commission up to 17 July, 2022 was amounting to Rs. 4,349.93 million. However, audit was unable to verify whether such overpayments had been recov-ered by the corporation or a basis to recover the overpaid dealers' commission had been established up to date.
Audit was unable to ensure whether, the consent of the board had been obtained by circulation of the decision or even through a virtual meeting with the members of the board over a week up to date.

According to the above analysis, it was observed that the decision to remove approved upper and lower CAP on dealer com-mission had been taken without proper financial evaluation about the present and future economic condition of the Corporation and proper evaluation of the financial impact of the decision to general public. Therefore, it is observed the necessity of given a due con-sideration before continuation of decision for long."

solar energy . , , one-fourth of the total fuel cost , 80 cost . solar 34-37 . , cost . , Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka Director General, Acting GM of CEB "Re: Requesting the Approval for the Revised Rooftop Solar PV Purchase Tariff" , .

"As per the General Policy Guideline for Electricity Industry issued by Ministry of Power under Section 5 of Sri Lanka Electricity Act No. 20 of 2009, Sri Lankas current energy policy has set a goal for renewable energy adoption in the electricity sector; 70 per cent of electricity generation from renewable sources by 2030. Accord-ingly, the Long-Term Generation Expansion Plan (2023-2042) approved by the Commission, has identified technology specific targets to achieve the above policy goal, including the rooftop/ground mounted solar capacity to be added to the system in order to achieve the above policy goal.

The Commission has observed that the solar PV (Rooftop and Ground) capacity addition targets of the Long-Term Generation Expansion Plan have not been achieved so far (Target up to 2024 = 1660MW, but only 1167MW achieved so far. Further, target in 2024 = 483MW, but only 261MW achieved so far and target in 2025 = 505MW) with an additional 3508MW of solar PV capacity still required by 2030."

Question, "That the sum of Rs. 598,000,000, for Head 119, Programme 01, Recurrent Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to.
Head 119, Programme 01, Recurrent Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.
Question, "That the sum of Rs. 25,000,000, for Head 119, Programme 01, Capital Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to.
Head 119, Programme 01, Capital Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.
Question, "That the sum of Rs. 463,000,000, for Head 119, Programme 02, Recurrent Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to.
Head 119, Programme 02, Recurrent Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.
Question, "That the sum of Rs. 20,056,000,000, for Head 119, Programme 02, Capital Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to.
Head 119, Programme 02, Capital Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.
It being 6.00 p.m., the Hon. Presiding Member left the Chair to report Progress.
Committee report Progress; to sit again on Tuesday, 04th March, 2025.
